titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Jock Truman Papers, 1852-2011, in the Archives of American Art AAA.trumjock
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Erin Kinhart

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 250494

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-01-28T08:58-0500

did.abstract: The papers of gallery director and art collector Jock Truman measure 4.0 linear feet and date from 1852 to 2011. Found within the collection are biographical material; correspondence with friends, family, artists, and others; records of the short-lived Truman Gallery; a few writings by Truman; printed material; artwork by Truman and others; and photographs of Truman, his partner Eric Green, friends, family, and the Truman-Green collection of artwork. A small amount of material documents his work at the Betty Parsons Gallery.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged as 7 series.

list.item: Series 1: Biographical Material, circa 1914-2006 (0.4 linear feet; Box 1)
Series 3: Truman Gallery Records, 1975-1979 (9 folders; Boxes 2, 6)
Series 5: Printed Material, 1852, 1940s-2010 (0.5 linear feet; Boxes 2, 6, OV 7)
Series 6: Artwork, 1860-1995 (0.3 linear feet; Boxes 2, 6, OV 7)
Series 7: Photographs, circa 1860s-2009 (1.9 linear feet; Boxes 2-6, OV 7)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Jock Truman (1920-2011) was an art collector, dealer, and gallery owner in New York, New York. Truman was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota, the son of Curtis Truman and Athelyn Amundsen Truman. He attended the University of Cincinnati from 1938 to 1941 and served in the U.S. Armed Forces in Brazil from 1942 to 1946. From 1946 to 1950 he attended the Harvard Graduate School of Design where he studied with Josef Albers, Gyorgy Kepes, and Hyman Bloom. During the 1950s he owned Thirty-Five River St. Inc., a Boston firm specializing in architectural and interior design.

Truman worked at Robert Isaacson Gallery for four years before moving to Betty Parsons Gallery, where he worked from 1961 to 1974. There he gained specialist knowledge regarding the work of Ad Reinhardt and assisted Reinhardt's widow in the evaluation of artworks after the artist's death. In 1974 he served as director of Parsons Gallery and he and Betty Parsons opened the Parsons-Truman Gallery, which operated as a joint venture from 1975 to 1976. In 1976 he opened Truman Gallery at 38 East 57th St. The gallery closed in 1979.

In 1989 Truman and his companion of over 30 years, Eric Green, moved to Miami. Truman and Green had a large collection of art which they donated to various museums including the Bass Museum of Art and the Museum of Contemporary Art in North Miami.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to Archives' Washington D.C. center. Contact Reference Services for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Jock Truman papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in 1982 and 2005-2006 by Jock Truman and 2011 by Truman via Eric Kane, Executor.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Jock Truman papers, 1852-2011. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed to a minimal level and a finding aid prepared by Erin Kinhart in 2014. The collection has been minimally rearranged and retains the existing/original folder titles when possible. All materials have been rehoused in archival folders and boxes for long-term stability, but often staples and other fasteners have not been removed. Materials within folders have not been rearranged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of gallery director and art collector Jock Truman measure 4.0 linear feet and date from 1852 to 2011. Found within the collection are biographical material; correspondence with friends, family, artists, and others; records of the short-lived Truman Gallery; a few writings by Truman; printed material; artwork by Truman and others; and photographs of Truman, his partner Eric Green, friends, family, and the Truman-Green collection of artwork. A small amount of material documents his work at the Betty Parsons Gallery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biographical material includes biographical summaries about Truman, various identification documents, school and military records, award certificates, and genealogy records on the Truman family. Also found are family records belonging to Truman's partner, Eric Green. Additionally there are records of the donation of a large portion of their art collection to the Bass Museum of Art and Museum of Contemporary Art in North Miami.

did.unittitle: Collection Donation to Bass Museum of Art
Mail Art Exhibition, Museum of Contemporary Art

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here is Truman's personal correspondence with family, friends, artists, and his partner, Eric Green. A small amount of professional correspondence is also included. Of note are postcards and letters from Christo and Jeanne-Claude and artist Leo Rabkin and his wife Dorothy. Handmade holiday cards and a few pieces of mail art sent to Truman are also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a letter from Louise Nevelson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes postcards from Henry Pearson, Betty Parsons, and Lucio Pozzi.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a handwritten letter from Harry S. Truman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The small amount of Truman Gallery records found here include gallery exhibition announcements, news clippings, press releases, and a few photographs of Jock Truman at the gallery. Additionally there are notes and letters from artist Jack Bergamini regarding an exhibition of his work and a folio of cartoons by Ad Reinhardt, published for his exhibition, "Ad Reinhardt: Art Comics and Satires," held at the gallery October 2-30, 1976.

did.unittitle: Notes and Letters from Jack Bergamini
Folio of Cartoons for "Ad Reinhardt: Art Comics and Satires"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writings by Jock Truman include a few one-page lists and notes as well as brief writings on New Realism, Agnes Martin, and ideas for a television program on collecting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material includes exhibition catalogs and announcements, event programs, new clippings, press releases, and travel publications. Also of note are two plastic bags from Keith Haring's original Pop Shop at 292 Lafayette Street in New York.

did.unittitle: Book, Changing Light by Carol Brockmon
Reproductions of Artwork and Blank Notecards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artwork is by Jock Truman and others. Included are handmade holiday cards by Truman and watercolors, pencil, and ink drawings completed by him in the early 1950s. Works by other artists are mostly unidentified but include a few pieces of mail art, sketches, a childhood portrait of Truman, and etchings and woodblock prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversize material also housed in OV 7.

did.unittitle: Oversize Artwork by Jock Truman, from Box 6, Folder 3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographs are extensive and depict Jock Truman's childhood, family, travel, military service in Brazil, and snapshots of events and social gatherings. Of note are portraits of Truman by Ruth Lazar, photographs of Truman with artists Lyman Kipp and William Congdon, and photographs of Truman at Betty Parsons Gallery. Also found are photographs of Truman with his partner, Eric Green, and many of Green's personal family photographs. Additionally there are inventory photographs of the Jock Truman and Eric Green collection of art.

did.unittitle: Portraits of Jock Truman by Ruth Lazar
Photographs of Jock Truman, Lyman Kipp, and William Congdon at Foundry
Photographs of Jock Truman as a Child
Photographs of Jock Truman and Eric Green

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversize material housed in Box 6, Folder 4

did.unittitle: Eric Green Personal and Family Photographs
Oversize Photograph of Jock Truman and Eric Green, from Box 3, Folder 9
